title: Department of Labor Announces $100 Million in Registered Apprenticeship Grants
excerpt: The U.S. Department of Labor announced $100 million in grants to expand Registered Apprenticeship programs in high-demand industries including electrical, HVAC, and construction trades. This investment is part of the Biden Administration's commitment to building pathways to good-paying jobs.
summary: DOL announces major funding for electrical apprenticeship expansion as part of infrastructure workforce initiative.

title: DOE Invests $45 Million in Clean Energy Workforce Training
excerpt: The Department of Energy is investing $45 million to train workers for clean energy jobs, with a focus on solar installation, EV charging infrastructure, and electrical grid modernization. The funding targets community colleges and union training programs.
summary: DOE funding targets electricians for clean energy transition jobs.

title: Google Commits $15 Million to Data Center Workforce Training
excerpt: Google announced a $15 million investment in workforce development programs to train electricians and technicians for data center construction and operations across the Midwest. The initiative partners with community colleges in Illinois, Iowa, and Ohio.
summary: Google funding electrician training for data center buildout in IL, IA, and OH.

title: Illinois DCEO Awards $8.2 Million in Workforce Training Grants
excerpt: The Illinois Department of Commerce and Economic Opportunity announced $8.2 million in workforce training grants, with $3.1 million designated for electrical and construction trades. Grant recipients include JATCs, community colleges, and private training providers.
summary: Illinois state funding for electrical training programs across the state.

title: IBEW-NECA Electrical Training Alliance Receives Federal Recognition
excerpt: The Electrical Training Alliance, jointly operated by IBEW and NECA, received recognition from the Department of Labor for its model apprenticeship curriculum serving over 300,000 apprentices nationwide.
summary: IBEW-NECA training programs receive federal endorsement, may unlock additional funding.

title: Electrician Shortage Threatens Data Center Expansion Plans
excerpt: Industry analysts warn that a critical shortage of licensed electricians could delay data center construction by 12-18 months. Major hyperscalers including Google, Microsoft, and Amazon are competing for limited skilled labor.
summary: Industry report documents electrician shortage impacting data center buildout timeline.
